user studies.name: Directory Browsing Experiment
author: turo1992-improve
johnson1993-categorical
user studies.subject: file system, compare treemaps and UNIX

hypotheses: treemaps are faster for global scope questions
unix would be faster for answering local questions

design.independent variables: 2 similar question sets x 7 tasks (5 timed local scope questions | 2 timed global scope questions)

participants.characterization: experienced computer users – no treemap knowledge

task list.task: Is there a Readme file in directory D? (local)
What are the file permissions for file F? (local)
How large is file F? (local)
How many subdirectories are in directory D? (local)
What is the smallest subdirectory of directory D? (local)
Do all of the files in directory D have a E-Extension?
How many sun binaries are in the D directory subtree? (global)
What is the size of the largest file in the D directory subtree? (global)

results: treemaps were faster for global scope questions
UNIX users made more errors (global scope questions)
subjects rated treemaps significantly better than UNIX
subjects found treemaps significantly more stimulating
unproven results: subjects performed comparably using both interfaces (local scope questions)
result based claims: Treemaps can significantly aid such tasks as locating large old files or clusters of files with similar attributes.
treemaps proved to be an effective visualization tool for global questions dealing with file hierarchies.

unified results.unified result: treemaps had faster task completion times for tree-related tasks (directory browsing) compared to UNIX shell
treemaps were rated higher (user satisfaction) compared to UNIX shell

proven claims.claim: Treemaps can significantly aid such tasks as locating large old files or clusters of files with similar attributes.
treemaps proved to be an effective visualization tool for global questions dealing with file hierarchies.

interpreted results.interpreted result: For global-scope tasks treemaps have faster task completion times than UNIX.
Treemaps are rated better (subjective rating) than UNIX.

results and analysis.notes: amateur effect assumed

user studies.name: GEnie Experiment
user studies.author: turo1992-improve
user studies.subject: financial data – compare treemaps (animated | small multiples) and hard-copy financial reports

design.independent variables: 3 visualization types (hard copy | animated treemaps | small multiples treemaps) x 12 tasks

task list.task: 12 questions on revenue and profits and data trends – no treemap knowledge

results: the performance of treemaps were faster (global trends)
unproven results: Subjectively there was a strong preference for the animated treemaps in terms of screen layout and information conveyed and capabilities

unified results.unified result: treemaps had faster task completion times for global tasks (financial data) compared to hardcopy financial reports

unified results.category: Design: Configuration of Focus and Context
unified results.unified result: animated treemaps were rated higher (preference) compared to small multiple treemaps

interpreted results.interpreted result: For global-scope tasks treemaps have faster task completion times than hardcopy financial reports.

results and analysis.notes: first half of experiment – users did not trust the visualization

user studies.name: US Budget Experiment
user studies.author: johnson1993-categorical
user studies.subject: budget data – compare treemaps and dynamic outline interfaces
claims: treemaps are an effective hierarchical visualization technique
treemaps are valuable data presentation tools for global location and comparison questions
Treemaps are not merely significantly faster than one of the best business tools available today, they are twice as fast.

hypotheses: Users will perform significantly better (Time, Accuracy, Confidence, Rating) with the treemap interface
Users will be able to locate new areas of high interest faster with treemaps
Users will be able to return to previous areas of high interest by memory faster with treemaps
Users will be able to make rough comparisons of high interest areas faster with treemaps.
User will have a better mental model of the data set after using the graphical treemap interface as evidenced by improved accuracy on incidental learning questions
Users will be more confident of their mental model of the data set after using the graphical treemap interface as evidenced by improved confidence ratings on incidental learning questions

design.independent variables: 2 interfaces (treemap | dynamic outline interface) x 29 questions (21 timed | 8 incidental learning –> categories – locate item full path, locate item below parent, locate item 2 levels below, locate item 3 levels below, locate a previous referenced item from memory, compare to previous referenced items)

participants.characterization: subjects from university population – no treemap knowledge

entry and debriefing.user opinion: 25 interface satisfaction level questions and free comments

task list.task: At level 2 which is larger – Cabinet Agencies or Miscellaneous Agencies?
Do the names of all of the level 3 items under Cabinet Agencies start with the word Department?
What is the name of the largest Department (level 3) under Cabinet Agencies?
What is the value of Health Care Financing Administration (level 4) under Department of Health?
What is the name of the largest level 4 item under Department of Defense Military?
What is the name of the largest level 4 item under Department of Defense Civil?
What is the name of the largest level 5 item under Miscellaneous Agencies?
What is the name of the largest level 4 item in the entire 1992 US Budget?
What is the value of Department of Treasury (level 3)?
In the Department of Defense_Military which level 4 item is larger – Research and Development or Procurement?
What is the name of the 2nd largest Department (level 3) under Cabinet Agencies?
Is the interest on the Public Debt more than half of the Department of Treasury?
Are Cabinet Agencies more than half of the 1992 US Budget?
What is the value of Procurement (level 4) under Department of Defense Military?
What is the name of the 3rd largest Department under Cabinet Agencies?
What is the name of the largest level 4 item under Department of Labor?
What is the name of the 2nd largest level 4 item under Miscellaneous Agencies?
What is the value of Interest on the Public Debt?
What is the name of the largest level 4 item under Other Independent Agencies in Miscellaneous Agencies?
How many level 4 items exceed 50.000?
Name the 7 level 4 items exceeding 50.000 in order of decreasing value?
What percent of the US Budget is the Interest on the Public Debt?
What percent of the US Budget is the Department of Treasury?
What percent of the US Budget is the National Space Council?
What percent of the US Budget is the Department of Defense Civil?
What percent of the US Budget is the Department of Commerce?
What percent of the US Budget is the Department of Health?
What percent of the US Budget is the Bureau of Alcohol Tobacco and Firearms?

results: Overall treemap users took only 50% of the time required by users of the dynamic outline interface
treemap users were significantly faster for 8 of 21 questions
As expected treemap users performed best (relatively speaking) on global questions
treemaps users were slightly more prone to errors. (significant difference was on one question)
unproven results: Dynamic outline users were not significantly faster for any of the questions or question types
Users generally liked both interfaces
subjects found treemaps to be more stimulating
Subjects found the interfaces easy to use
unproven claims: treemaps are valuable data presentation tools for […] comparison questions
paper excerpts.treemap rating: 1 out of 2 – twice as fast and effective for relative allocation questions

unified results.unified result: treemaps had faster task completion times for budget data exploration tasks compared to tables (Dynamic Outline Interface)

proven claims.claim: treemaps are an effective hierarchical visualization technique
treemaps are valuable data presentation tools for global location questions
Treemaps are not merely significantly faster than one of the best business tools available today, they are twice as fast.

interpreted results.interpreted result: For budget data exploration treemaps are faster than tables (Dynamic Outline Interface).

user studies.name: 3D Information Visualizations
user studies.author: wiss1999-tasksupport
user studies.subject: comparative study of three 3D information visualizations (Information Landscape | Cam Tree | Information Cube)
claims: The results of the study indicate that the subjects were significantly faster with the Information Landscape when compared with both other visualizations.
The Cam Tree was significantly faster than the Information Cube.
Our observations during the study indicate that local and global overview are extremely important factors.

hypotheses: Cam Tree would provide the best support (for search tasks), while the Information Cube and the Information Landscape would suffer from the lack of global context.
performance would be affected by the way the visualization separates directories and files. For count tasks the Information Landscape was expected to be the best, and the Cam Tree worst.
The Information Cube was thought to give the least support for compare tasks since children on lower levels are occluded.

design.independent variables: 3 vis (Information Landscape | Cam Tree | Information Cube) x 6 datasets

entry and debriefing.user opinion: questionnaire at the end to rate visualizations

task list.task: find two directories and click on them in the visualization
count the number of files in each of the two directories found in the previous task
compare the two directories and select the one that contained most descendants

results: A total of 45 tasks were either timed-out or aborted by the user. All these were tasks using the Information Cube.
there is a significant difference between the times to perform the tasks with the tree visualizations. (Info Cube slower than Cam tree slower than landscape)
For all three tasks, the Chi-Square Test showed that the error frequencies were indeed related to the visualization used to perform the task. (info cube most)
result based claims: the Information Cube performed worst for all tasks, and the Information Landscape performed best.
To summarize, our observations show that the possibility to get a good local and global overview is the single most important factor in supporting the types of tasks that we studied.

So perhaps, 3D user interfaces are most suitable in applications that are more about exploration and long-term learning, where stimulating, aesthetically pleasing interfaces can be expected to be important.

unified results.unified result: 3D treemaps (Information Cube) led to the most errors, time-outs and aborts compared to 2.5D nodelink visualizations (Information Landscape, Cam Tree)

proven claims.claim: the Information Cube performed worst for all tasks, and the Information Landscape performed best.

To summarize, our observations show that the possibility to get a good local and global overview is the single most important factor in supporting the types of tasks that we studied (find, count, compare contained descendants).

So perhaps, 3D user interfaces are most suitable in applications that are more about exploration and long-term learning, where stimulating, aesthetically pleasing interfaces can be expected to be important.

interpreted results.interpreted result: 3D treemaps (Information Cube) lead to more errors and time-outs / aborts compared to Information Landscape (2.5D Nodelink) and Cam Tree (2.5D Nodelink).
3D user interfaces are most suitable in applications that are more about exploration and long-term learning, where stimulating, aesthetically pleasing interfaces can be expected to be important.

notes: Information Cube the only real 3D visualization. Cam Tree and Information Landscape are 2.5D visualizations

user studies.name: Sunburst vs. Treemap (small)
user studies.author: stasko2000-structures
user studies.subject: compare how treemap and sunburst assist people in performing typical file tasks for small trees
claims: performance trends favored the Sunburst tool with respect to correct task performance,
Performance with Treemap tended to improve over time and use, suggesting a greater learning cost that was partially recouped over time.
participants strongly preferred the Sunburst tool, citing better ability to convey structure and hierarchy

hypotheses: treemaps will be better for tasks involving file sizes, such as a comparison of sizes or finding the largest file, with respect to both accuracy and time.
sunburst will be better for search tasks such as finding a particular file somewhere in the directory structure

design.independent variables: 2 tool (treemap, sunburst) x 2 phase of tool x 2 dataset x 16 tasks

participants.characterization: students (computer science and varied backgrounds – no treemap knowledge)

entry and debriefing.training: tutorial and eight example tasks for each visualization
entry and debriefing.user opinion: at the end of each session phase 15 likert-style questions and 4 open-format opinion questions

task list.task: Identify the (second) largest files (2 tasks)
Identify the largest directory
Locate a file given the entire path and name (3 tasks)
Locate a file given only the name (2 tasks)
Identify the deepest subdirectory
Identify a directory containing files of a type
Identify a file based on type and size
Compare two files by size and identify the larger
Locate two duplicate directory structures containing the same files
Compare two directories by size and identify the larger
Compare two directories by number of files and identify the one with more files

results: the dataset had a significant effect on accuracy
the tool had an significant effect on number of correct answers (sunburst higher than treemap) for one dataset
unproven results: no effect for tool or phase (Hierarchy B) on accuracy
the interaction of tool and phase was not significant (accuracy)
no reliable effect of tool / phase or interaction on completion times for both datasets
unproven claims: performance trends favored the Sunburst tool with respect to correct task performance,
Performance with Treemap tended to improve over time and use, suggesting a greater learning cost that was partially recouped over time.
participants strongly preferred the Sunburst tool, citing better ability to convey structure and hierarchy

unified results.unified result: treemaps might have a lower accuracy compared to sunburst

interpreted results.interpreted result: Treemaps might have a lower accuracy than sunburst.

results and analysis.notes: since dataset had an effect, results might be not valid

user studies.name: Topology and Node Size
user studies.author: barlow2001-comparison
user studies.subject: Compare ability of treemap, icicle plot, polar treemaps (sunburst) and organization charts to communicate the topology of tree and support comparisons of node size

design.independent variables: 4 view (random – treemap | icicle plot | circular treemap | organization charts) x 5 tasks

participants.characterization: software developers / testers / technical writers – no treemap knowledge

task list.task: Decide whether the tree is binary or N-ary.
Decide whether the tree is balanced or unbalanced.
Find the deepest common ancestor of the 2 given nodes.
Count the number of levels.
Select the three largest leaves.

results: The participants' performance with the treemap was worse in the largest leaves task than with the other views.
In the three tasks in which the participants' accuracy with the treemap was significantly less than with the other views, their response times were significantly slower.
The treemap was uniformly disliked by the participants
Their response times (treemap users) were slower in four tasks. Their response accuracy was lower in three tasks.
unproven results: In comparison, treemaps and tree rings require the user to learn how to interpret the structure.
their performance while using it was worse than with the other three views.

unified results.unified result: nested treemaps had a lower accuracy for tree-attribute tasks compared to nodelink
nested treemaps had slower task completion times for tree-attribute tasks compared to nodelink
nested treemaps were disliked by participants for tree-attribute tasks compared to nodelink
nested treemaps had a lower accuracy for tree-attribute tasks compared to sunburst
nested treemaps had slower task completion times for tree-attribute tasks compared to sunburst
nested treemaps were disliked by participants for tree-attribute tasks compared to sunburst
nested treemaps had a lower accuracy for tree-attribute tasks compared to icicle plot
nested treemaps had slower task completion times for tree-attribute tasks compared to icicle plot
nested treemaps were disliked by participants for tree-attribute tasks compared to icicle plot

interpreted results.interpreted result: For tree attribute-related tasks nested treemaps perform worse (accuracy, task completion time and user satisfaction) than nodelink, sunburst and icicle plot.

results and analysis.notes: Tasks mainly not suitable to treemaps

user studies.name: Compare Layout Algorithms
user studies.author: bederson2002-quantum
user studies.subject: Compare strip and squarified and pivot layout algorithm
claims: compared to other layout algorithms, ordered treemaps are more stable, while maintaining relatively favorable aspect ratios of the constituent rectangles.
Thus ordered treemaps may be a good choice in situations where readability, usability and smooth updating all are important concerns.

design.independent variables: 3 algorithms (squarified |  pivot | strip) x 10 random trees

task list.task: Find node with ID X.

results: significant difference (measured time) between the squarified treemap algorithm and the other two (squarified faster)
significant difference (subjective preference) between all three algorithms (strip > ordered (pivot) > squarified)
unproven results: no significant difference (time) between strip and ordered (pivot)
result based claims: We found that strip treemaps offer the best combination, substantially improving readability while maintaining good aspect ratios and stability, and thus are likely to be preferred for a broad range of applications.
when stability or aspect ratios are crucial, the slice-and-dice or squarified algorithms, respectively, may be more appropriate.
The user study results suggest that the readability metric is predictive of real-world performance on simple search tasks.

While the time measurement for the strip and pivot treemap were not significantly different, the trend was in the same direction as the readability metric (strip faster than pivot which is faster than squarified), and the difference between the three algorithms for subjective preference was significant, and in the same direction as the readability metric.

unified results.unified result: treemaps using a squarified layout had slower click times for item search tasks compared to ordered (pivot-by-middle) layout and strip layout
treemaps using a strip layout were rated higher (subjective preference) for item search tasks compared to ordered (pivot-by-middle) layout and squarified layout
treemaps using an ordered (pivot-by-middle) layout were rated higher (subjective preference) for item search tasks compared to squarified layout

proven claims.claim: The user study results suggest that the readability metric is predictive of real-world performance on simple search tasks.

interpreted results.interpreted result: For simple item search tasks treemaps using an ordered (pivot-by-middle) layout or strip layout have faster task completion times than treemaps using a squarified layout.

For simple item search tasks treemaps using a strip layout are rated higher (subjective preference) than treemaps using an ordered (pivot-by-middle) layout which are rated higher (subjective preference) than treemaps using a squarified layout.
For simple item search tasks the readability metric seems to be predictive of the real-world time-to-click measure.

notes: all proven claims are valid for finding tasks only (id = number of node)
only a vague correlation between readability metric and time-to-click measurement shown
additional extensive metric based evaluation of aspect ratio, change (stability), and readability

user studies.name: Compare to Beamtrees
user studies.author: vanHam2003-beamtrees
user studies.subject: Pilot Study – Compare beamtrees 2D and 3D to nested treemaps and cushion treemaps
claims: A small user study indicated that beamtrees are significantly more effective than nested treemaps and cushion treemaps for the extraction of global hierarchical information.

hypotheses: beamtrees are more efficient in globally oriented, structure-related tasks
beamtrees are less efficient in size-related tasks

design.independent variables: 4 visualization methods (2D beamtree | 3D beamtree | nested treemap | cushion treemap) x 2 sizes (200 and 1000) x 5 tasks

participants.characterization: co-workers unfamiliar with beamtree but some with treemap concepts

entry and debriefing.training: explanation in general and small test for all visualization methods and one timed trial

task list.task: select 3 largest leaves (file size)
determine level of node (tree topology, depth)
determine total levels of tree (tree topology, levels)
determine deepest common ancestor of 2 nodes (tree topology, common parent)
memorize the position of 2 predetermined nodes (node memory)

results: 3D beamtrees perform significantly better than both of the treemap methods in time and accuracy (level task)
unproven results: all remaining results (error rate and response time) were not significant
result based claims: We expect 3D beamtrees to perform significantly better than regular treemaps when it comes to global structural information such as maximum depth or balance.
unproven claims: A small user study indicated that beamtrees are significantly more effective than nested treemaps and cushion treemaps for the extraction of global hierarchical information.

unified results.unified result: nested treemaps had a lower accuracy for level-counting tasks (tree attribute tasks) compared to 3D beamtrees
cushion treemaps had a lower accuracy for level-counting tasks (tree attribute tasks) compared to 3D beamtrees
nested treemaps had slower task completion times for level-counting tasks (tree attribute tasks) compared to 3D beamtrees
cushion treemaps had slower task completion times for level-counting tasks (tree attribute tasks) compared to 3D beamtrees

proven claims.claim: We expect 3D beamtrees to perform significantly better than regular treemaps when it comes to global structural information such as maximum depth or balance.

interpreted results.interpreted result: For tasks related to level counting (global structural information such as maximum depth or balance) nested treemaps (treemaps with margin) and cushion treemaps perform worse (accuracy and task completion time) than 3D beamtrees.

user studies.name: Compare 5 well-known tree visualizations and windows explorer
user studies.author: kobsa2004-systems
user studies.subject: Determine whether solving tasks in the six systems differ with respect to task completion times | accuracy and user satisfaction and why this may be the case.
claims: Significant system and task type effects and an interaction between system and task type were found.

hypotheses: there are no differences in completion times, accuracy and user satisfaction between visualization types

design.independent variables: 6 visualization types (treemap, cushion treemaps (sequoia view), beamtrees, star tree studio, tree viewer, windows explorer) x 15 tasks

entry and debriefing.training: 1/2 hour training in small groups and controlled practice for 20 minutes

task list.task: What is the maximum depth of the ebay hierarchy? (structure)
Is the tree balanced or unbalanced? (structure)
Find the name of the parent directory of the directory BMW? (structure)
Which directory has the greatest number of immediate subdirectories? (structure)
Which file was modified most recently? (attributes)
Find the total number of bottom-level directories under Automobiles? (structure)
Which bottom-level directory of the ebay item hierarchy has the largest number of files? (structure)
Find a file of type css and write down its name. (attributes)
Find the directory that contains the most png type files. (structure)
Find all files added on Feb. 19 2003. write down their file names. (attributes)
Locate the file labeled 1990.html. (attributes)
What is the name of the largest file in the ebay items hierarchy? (attributes)
Find the number of directories without a file of type js. (attributes)
Which directory includes a deeper hierarchy flutes or guitars. (structure)
Find the two duplicate occurrences of the directory 1869. Indicate their path names. (structure)

results: treemap yielded the highest number of correct answers. statistically significant higher than beamtree and treeviewer
cushion had significantly more correct answers than beamtree, tree viewer
treemap had significantly more correct answers than beamtree, cushion, star tree (structure-related) and beamtree, treeviwer (attribute-related)
cushion had significantly more correct answers than beamtree, tree viewer (attribute-related)
treemap was significantly faster than beamtree, tree viewer, cushion, star tree
cushion was significantly faster than beamtree, tree viewer
treemap was significantly faster than beamtree, cushion (structure-related) and beamtree, treeviwer (attribute-related)
cushion was significantly slower than star tree (structure-related) and faster for beamtree, tree viewer, star tree (attribute-related)
treemap was significantly better (ease of use) than beamtree and (effectiveness) beamtree, treeviewer
cushion was significantly better than beamtree and worse than explorer (ease of use) and (effectiveness) beamtree
result based claims: the video analysis revealed that treemaps most useful feature was its rich color coding and filtering functionality
the videos confirmed concerns from the literature that global structure tasks (Q1, Q2, Q4, Q7) are somewhat difficult to solve in treemap (but nevertheless in the upper midfield)
it seems that the usefulness of treemap can be enhanced by integrating more search functionality
the video analysis confirmed that subjects had indeed problems with structure-related questions, specifically regarding level and sibling detection (cushion)
unproven claims: The quantitative analysis showed no significant differences between Treemap and Explorer.

cushion treemaps had faster task completion times for attribute-related tasks compared to nodelink (Star Tree) [ibUI]
cushion treemaps had slower task completion times for structure-related tasks compared to nodelink (Star Tree) [ibUI]

nested (titlebar) treemaps and cushion treemaps had a higher accuracy for attribute-related tasks compared to botanical trees (Tree Viewer) [ibUI]
nested (titlebar) treemaps and cushion treemaps had faster task completion times for attribute-related tasks compared to botanical trees (Tree Viewer) [ibUI]
nested (titlebar) treemaps and cushion treemaps were rated better for attribute-related tasks compared to botanical trees (Tree Viewer) [ibUI]
cushion treemaps had a lower accuracy for structure-related tasks compared to windows explorer [ibUI]
cushion treemaps had slower task completion times for structure-related tasks compared to windows explorer [ibUI]
cushion treemaps were rated lower (user satisfaction) compared to windows explorer [ibUI]
significant differences between nested (titlebar) treemaps and windows explorer were not found

claims: when comparing leaf nodes the effectiveness of bar charts versus treemaps is modulated by the data density.
As data density increases, the accuracy difference equalizes, with treemaps matching bar charts at data densities past 4096 leaves.
We also find that even at relatively low data densities treemaps result in faster comparisons than bar charts.

hypotheses: we hypothesized that at high densities a treemap would provide a more effective display than a bar chart.
we hypothesized that at lower densities the bar chart would be more perceptually effective than a treemap.

design.independent variables: 2 chart types (treemap | bar chart) x 5 (LN und NN 256 | 512 | 2014 | 2048 | 4096) or 8 data densities (LL 256 | 512 | 2014 | 2048 | 4096 | 6000 | 7000 | 8000) x 4 true percentage (LL and NN 32 | 48 | 58 | 72 or LN 3 | 8 | 13 | 17) x 3 comparison types (leaf x leaf | L x inner node | N x N)

results: LL bar charts were significantly more accurate at the 512, 1024, and 2046 leaf conditions

LL responses with treemaps became significantly faster at the higher densities
NL found a strong main effect of chart type on accuracy
NL significant interaction between chart type and density – treemaps maintained their accuracy as data density increased, while bar charts trended towards higher error rates
result based claims: when comparing leaf nodes the effectiveness of bar charts versus treemaps is modulated by the data density

At low data densities, bar charts result in significantly more accurate estimations without a significant difference in response time. As data density increases, the accuracy difference equalizes, with treemaps matching bar charts at data densities past 4096 leaves.
Use Bar Charts at Low Densities, Treemaps at High Densities.
Use Treemaps When Comparing Non-Leaf Nodes.

unified results.unified result: For leaf-leaf comparison tasks with low density, 2-level hierarchy data treemaps had a lower accuracy compared to bar charts.
For leaf-leaf comparison tasks with high density, 2-level hierarchy data treemaps had faster task completion times compared to bar charts.
For leaf-node comparison tasks with 2-level hierarchy data treemaps had a better accuracy than bar charts, intesifying with increasing data density.
For node-node comparison tasks with 2-level hierarchy data treemaps had a better accuracy than bar charts, intesifying with increasing data density.

proven claims.claim: when comparing leaf nodes the effectiveness of bar charts versus treemaps is modulated by the data density.

At low data densities, bar charts result in significantly more accurate estimations without a significant difference in response time. As data density increases, the accuracy difference equalizes, with treemaps matching bar charts at data densities past 4096 leaves.
We also find that even at relatively low data densities treemaps result in faster comparisons than bar charts.
Use Bar Charts at Low Densities, Treemaps at High Densities.
Use Treemaps When Comparing Non-Leaf Nodes.

user studies.name: Locus of Control and Containment Metaphor

claims: Participants with an internal locus of control perform more poorly with visualizations that employ a containment metaphor, while those with an external locus of control perform well with such visualizations.

hypotheses: Our hypothesis is that individual differences based on locus of control are more affected by layout in this sense than by visual encoding or interaction style.
We hypothesize that users with a more external locus of control are more willing to adapt their thinking to unfamiliar visual metaphors than those with an internal locus of control.

An individual with a more internal locus of control will show a performance decrease when using layouts with a strong containment metaphor, while those with a more external locus of control will not show this decrease.

significant main effects of question type (search faster than inferential)
significant main effects of Locus of Control
internal LOC participants were slower at answering questions correctly
significant interaction between view condition and question type
significant interaction between LOC group and question type (internal slower with inferential and equal with search)
raw Locus of Control score correlates significantly with correct response time on nested boxes
participants with an external loc answered more questions correctly
V1 and V2 were rated significantly more positively than V3 and V4
unproven results: average loc participants show no response time difference between views
no significant response time difference between views (search tasks)
participants with an external LOC answer questions in V4 (nested boxes) faster than other participants, although they answer questions in V1 faster as well
result based claims: participants with an external LOC responded faster to inferential questions than did participants with an internal LOC
unproven claims: participants with an external LOC responded faster particularly in a visualization with a containmentbased visual metaphor (V4).

proven claims.claim: Participants with an internal locus of control perform more poorly with visualizations that employ a containment metaphor, while those with an external locus of control perform well with such visualizations.
participants with an external LOC responded faster to inferential questions than did participants with an internal LOC

we conclude that using the hierarchical visualization provides more benefits than the flat visualization.

hypotheses: A1 Map-like visualisations allow lay users to perceive hierarchies more accurately than treemaps do.
S1 Map-like visualisations allow lay users to perceive hierarchies faster than treemaps do.

design.independent variables: 3 visualization types (treemap | nested treemap | map-like) x 4 groups (type order) x 5 images on each page

results: difference in accuracy between non-nested and nested treemaps was highly significant (nested better)
difference in accuracy between nested treemaps and map-like was highly significant (map-like better)
the difference in speed between non-nested treemaps and map-like visualisations was marginally significant (non-nested better)
the difference in speed between nested treemaps and map-like visualisations was highly statistically significant (treemap better)
unproven results: the difference in speed between non-nested and nested treemaps was not statistically significant
result based claims: (1) map-like visualisations are indeed better in terms of accuracy than both forms of treemaps we evaluated
(2) of the two types of treemap evaluated, the non-nested treemap performs very poorly in terms of accuracy.

unified results.unified result: nested (titlebar) treemaps had a higher accuracy for relationship-identification tasks compared to non-nested treemaps

map-like treemaps had slower task solving times for relationship-identification tasks compared to non-nested treemaps and nested (titlebar) treemaps

participants performed significantly better with the complex nodelink compared to the less complex nodelink for task T2

result based claims: Because treemaps do not explicitly follow this structural order with several clearly distinct hierarchy levels, participants constantly have to reorient and remember which elements were already processed. We suspect that this discrepancy is partially responsible for the participants’ bad performance with treemaps.

It becomes apparent that fixations concentrate mainly in the upper parts of the relevant regions. Due to the self-occluding design of treemaps (inner nodes), these are the only parts of occluded regions that are directly observable.

These results suggest that the treemap visualization is indeed effective in promoting task-relevant fixations due to its maximization of screen space. However, these benefits in visual perception are not reflected in the user performance measure.
This could be seen as an indicator of the high relevance of previous experience with visualization techniques compared to their visual arrangement.

user studies.name: Wrapped Bars – Comparison

user studies.subject: Compare Treemaps to Wrapped Bars for sorted numeric data – size comparison
claims: Our analysis found that wrapped bars perceptually outperform treemaps in all three tasks for dense visualization of non-hierarchical, sorted numeric data.
Our results suggest that wrapped bars outperform treemaps in perceptual accuracy for all three tasks.
Treemaps are also commonly used in practice to display non-hierarchical data in order to scale to more records than possible with a standard bar chart.
The tasks were designed to apply fairly to all chart designs.
Overall, our results suggest that treemaps are not a preferable design when records do not have an explicit hierarchy.

design.independent variables: 2 vis (treemap | wrapped bar)[between-subjects] x 3 data densities (75 | 150 | 300) x 10 true percentage

entry and debriefing.training: training trials before and in between and animated demos

task list.task: Determine which is larger item and by how much (in percent). (comparison)

results: Our participants estimated relative sizes of records more accurately using wrapped bars compared to treemaps (comparison)
unproven results: Increasing data density did not have a substantial effect on treemap accuracy. (comparison)
at the highest density level (300 records), wrapped bars performed marginally worse, and its performance gap from treemaps is narrower.
The response times was similar (comparison)
result based claims: Overall, our results and analysis show that wrapped bars yield higher perceptual performance compared to treemaps in a nonhierarchical setting.
wrapped bars should be considered over treemaps as an effective and flexible design to present dense, sorted, non-hierarchical numeric data.

For element locating tasks with imposed hierarchy datasets treemaps using a Slice-and-dice layout or a Strip layout have fastest task completion times in comparison to other treemap layout algorithms (Squarified, Pivot-by-middle, Pivot-by-split-size, Pivot-by-size, Ordered-Squarified).

For element locating tasks with true hierarchy datasets treemaps using a Squarified layout have slowest task completion times in comparison to other treemap layout algorithms (Slice-and-dice, Strip, Pivot-by-middle, Pivot-by-split-size, Pivot-by-size, Ordered-Squarified).

For visual comparison tasks with true hierarchy datasets treemaps using a Pivot-by-split-size layout have slowest task completion times in comparison to other treemap layout algrorithms (Slice-and-dice, Pivot-by-middle, Pivot-by-size and Strip).

For visual comparison tasks with imposed hierarchy datasets treemaps using a Slice-and-dice layout have fastest task completion times in comparison to other treemap layout algrorithms (Squarified, Pivot-by-middle, Pivot-by-size, Strip and Ordered-Squarified).

For correlation exploring tasks with imposed hierarchy datasets treemaps using a Slice-and-dice layout have fastest task completion times in comparison to other treemap layout algorithms (Squarified, Pivot-by-middle, Pivot-by-split-size, Pivot-by-size, Strip, Ordered-Squarified).
Summarized: For element locating tasks and visual comparison tasks with true hierarchy datasets treemaps using a Slice-and-dice layout are most suitable.

Summarized: For element locating tasks, visual comparison tasks and correlation exploring tasks with imposed hierarchy datasets Slice-and-dice was also identified as the most suitable algorithm for representing false hierarchy (imposed hierarchy).
Summarized: For time series datasets treemaps susing a Slice-and-dice layout or a Strip layout are suitable.

user studies.name: Crop Circles

user studies.subject: Compare Crop Circles with Treemap 4.1 and SpaceTree
claims: CropCircles is effective in conveying topological information and addresses the weaknesses of the other two tools

design.independent variables: 3 vis (Crop Circles | Treemap 4.1 | SpaceTree) x 8 tasks <- (2 datasets task dependent)

task list.task: Find an unknown node. (navigational)
Find an unknown node. (navigational)
Return to Previously Visited Nodes. (navigational)
Comparison of Subtrees. (topology recognition)
Find the Bushiest Child Node. (topology recognition)
Find the Largest Subtree. (topology recognition)
Find a Deepest Node. (topology recognition)
Find 3 Nodes with at Least 10 Children. (topology recognition)
Find 3 Top-level Nodes that Root a subtree of Depth of at Least 5. (topology recognition)

results: Space Tree was significantly faster than Crop Circles in T1 (Find an unknown node).
Space Tree was significantly faster than Treemap in T1 (Find an unknown node).
Crop Circles was significantly faster than Treemap in T2 (Return to prev node).
Space Tree was significantly faster than Treemap in T2 (Return to prev node).
Crop Circles was significantly faster than Treemap in T4 (Find the bushiest node).
Space Tree was significantly faster than Treemap in T4 (Find the bushiest node).
Crop Circles showed a statistically significant lower error rate compared to Treemap in T6 (deepest node).
Crop Circles was significantly faster than Space Tree in T7 (Find nodes with 10 children).
Treemap was significantly faster than Space Tree in T7 (Find nodes with 10 children).
unproven results: all remaining results were not statistically significant
result based claims: CropCircles performed well against Treemap and SpaceTree in topological tasks.
In this sense CropCircles is the most balanced of the three tools in topology recognition tasks.
By avoiding Treemap’s and SpaceTree’s weaknesses, CropCircles is an appropriate visualization for class hierarchy.
However, we are able to show that in topological tasks, CropCircles’s performance is comparable to strengths of the two other tools, and is an improvement over their known weaknesses.
unproven claims: CropCircles performed well against SpaceTree in topological tasks.
In this sense CropCircles is the most balanced of the three tools in topology recognition tasks.
However, we are able to show that in topological tasks, CropCircles’s performance is an improvement over their (other tools) known weaknesses.

rectangular nested (titlebar) treemaps (Treemap 4.1) had slower task completion times for returning tasks compared to nodelink (Space Tree)
rectangular nested (titlebar) treemaps (Treemap 4.1) had slower task completion times for identifying the bushiest child node task compared to nodelink (Space Tree)
rectangular nested (titlebar) treemaps (Treemap 4.1) had faster task completion times for structural filtering tasks compared to nodelink (Space Tree)
un-labeled circular treemaps (Crop Circles) had slower task completion times for finding tasks compared to nodelink (Space Tree)
circular treemaps (Crop Circles) had faster task completion times for structural filtering tasks compared to nodelink (Space Tree).
circular treemaps (Crop Circles) had faster task completion times for returning tasks compared to rectangular nested (titlebar) treemaps (Treemap 4.1)
circular treemaps (Crop Circles) had faster task completion times for identifying the bushiest child node tasks compared to rectangular nested (titlebar) treemaps (Treemap 4.1)
circular treemaps (Crop Circles) had a higher accuracy for identifying deepest node tasks compared to rectangular nested (titlebar) treemaps (Treemap 4.1)

proven claims.claim: Crop Circles is effective in conveying topological information
Crop Circles is an appropriate visualization for class hierarchy.
However, we are able to show that in topological tasks, Crop Circles’s performance is comparable to strengths of the two other tools
Crop Circles performed well against Treemap in topological tasks

interpreted results.interpreted result: For finding tasks, returning tasks and identifying the bushiest child node tasks rectangular treemaps (Treemap 4.1) have slower task completion times than nodelink (Space Tree).
For structural filtering tasks rectangular treemaps (Treemap 4.1) and circular treemaps (Crop Circles) have faster task completion times than nodelink (Space Tree).
For finding tasks circular treemaps (Crop Circles) have slower task completion times than nodelink (Space Tree).
For returning tasks and identifying the bushiest child node tasks circular treemaps (Crop Circles) have faster task completion times than rectangular treemaps (Treemap 4.1).
For identifying the deepest node tasks circular treemaps (Crop Circles) have a higher accuracy than rectangular treemaps (Treemap 4.1).

user studies.name: Software Systems as Cities
user studies.author: wettel2011-softwarecities
user studies.subject: provide experimental evidence of the viability of our approach in the context of program comprehension
claims: CodeCity leads to a statistically significant increase in terms of task correctness and decrease in task completion time.

hypotheses: H1 The tool impacts the correctness of the solutions to program comprehension tasks.
H2 The tool impacts the time required to complete program comprehension tasks.

design.independent variables: 2 vis (eclipse and excel | Code City between-subjects) x 2 system size (medium | large between-subjects) x 10 tasks

entry and debriefing.user opinion: debriefing questionnaire and level of difficulty for each tasks and feedback

task list.task: Locate all the unit test classes of the system and identify the convention (or lack therof) used by the developers to organize the tests. (Structural understanding)
Look for the term T1 in the names of classes and their attributes and methods, and describe the spread of these classes in the system. (Concept location)
Look for the term T2 in the names of classes and their attributes and methods, and describe the spread of these classes in the system. (Concept location)

Evaluate the change impact of class C by considering its caller classes (classes invoking any of its methods). The assessment is done in terms of both intensity (number of potentially affected classes) and dispersion (how these classes are distributed in the package structure).
Find the three classes with the highest number of methods (NOM) in the system. (Metric-based analysis)
Find the three classes with the highest average number of lines of code per method in the system. (Metric-based analysis)
Identify the package with the highest percentage of god classes in the system. (Focused design assessment)
Identify the god class containing the largest number of methods in the system. (Focused design assessment)
Identify the dominant class-level design problem (the design problem that affects the largest number of classes) in the system. (Holistic design assessment)
Write an overview of the class-level design problems in the system. Describe your most interesting or unexpected observations. (Holistic design assessment)

results: significant effect of tool on correctness (CodeCity higher correctness, larger diff for larger system)
significant effect of system size on correctness (higher for medium system)
significant effect of tool on completion time (CodeCity was faster, larger diff for larger system)
significant effect of system size on completion time (faster for medium system)
Code City was significantly more correct than the base line for task A2.2
Code City was significantly more correct than the base line for task A3
Code City was significantly faster than the base line for task B1.2
unproven results: the interaction of tool and system size on correctness was not significant
the interaction of tool and system size on completion time was not significant
result based claims: The main result of the experiment is that our approach leads to an improvement, in both correctness (+24%) and completion time (-12%), over the state-of-the-practice exploration tools.
in the case of focused tasks, i.e., tasks which require very precise answers, CodeCity did not perform better than Eclipse+Excel
our approach managed to be on a par with Excel. (focused tasks)
tasks that benefit from an overview of the system, CodeCity constantly outperformed the baseline.

unified results.unified result: Treemaps (CodeCity) had a higher accuracy for program comprehension tasks compared to state-of-the-practice software exploration tools (Eclipse+Excel).

Treemaps (CodeCity) had a higher accuracy for program comprehension tasks related to the distribution of similar named components compared to state-of-the-practice software exploration tools (Eclipse+Excel).
Treemaps (CodeCity) had a higher accuracy for program comprehension tasks related to component dependencies compared to state-of-the-practice software exploration tools (Eclipse+Excel).
Treemaps (CodeCity) had faster task completion times for program comprehension tasks compared to state-of-the-practice software exploration tools (Eclipse+Excel).
Treemaps (CodeCity) had faster task completion times for identification of leaf node extrema tasks compared to state-of-the-practice software exploration tools (Eclipse+Excel).
CodeCity performed equal for focused tasks (requiring very precise answers) but outperformed the baseline for tasks regarding an overview of te system.

proven claims.claim: CodeCity leads to a statistically significant increase in terms of task correctness and decrease in task completion time.
The main result of the experiment is that our approach leads to an improvement, in both correctness (+24%) and completion time (-12%), over the state-of-the-practice exploration tools.
in the case of focused tasks, i.e., tasks which require very precise answers, CodeCity did not perform better than Eclipse+Excel
our approach managed to be on a par with Excel. (focused tasks)
tasks that benefit from an overview of the system, CodeCity constantly outperformed the baseline.

interpreted results.interpreted result: For program comprehension tasks treemaps (CodeCity) perform better (accuracy and task completion time) than state-of-the-practice software exploration tools (Eclipse + Excel).
For focused tasks (requiring very precise answers) treemaps (CodeCity) and state-of-the-practice software exploration tools (Eclipse + Excel) performed equal (no differences could be confirmed).
For leaf node extrema tasks treemaps (CodeCity) have faster task completion times than state-of-the-practice software exploration tools (Eclipse + Excel).

notes: controlled participants: 2 experience levels (beginner, advanced) x 2 background (academia, industry)
laboratory implementation emulated with virtual images

user studies.name: Color Schemes – Data Discrimination
user studies.author: xie2017-coloraesthetics
user studies.subject: demonstrate the effectiveness of our coloring method in improving data discrimination in various conditions
claims: Our experimental results confirm the superiority of our method in terms of improved data discrimination of the treemaps.

design.independent variables: 3 layouts (3x strip | between-subjects) x 3 coloring methods (random | sequential | c-vpa) x 3 dataset size (9 | 15 | 20)

task list.task: sort the data block according to the perceived size

results: coloring method had a significant effect on time (c-vpa faster than random and sequential)
dataset size had a significant effect on time
a significant interaction of coloring method and dataset size was found which effects time
coloring method had a significant effect on accuracy (c-vpa better than random and sequential)
dataset size had a significant effect on accuracy
a significant interaction of coloring method and dataset size was found which effects accuracy
result based claims: compared with Random and Sequential, our proposed method indeed helps users better discriminate data blocks with similar sizes

unified results.unified result: treemaps colored with the C-VPA model had a higher accuracy for node sorting tasks compared to treemaps colored with random model or sequential model

proven claims.claim: compared with Random and Sequential, our proposed method indeed helps users better discriminate data blocks with similar sizes

interpreted results.interpreted result: The C-VPA coloring model helped users to sort similar sized data blocks more accurate and faster compared to random coloring.

results and analysis.notes: sequential color scheme not fairly adapted (lightness range was too small)

user studies.subject: examine the improvement of the c-vpa method on aesthetics and data discrimination simultaneously
claims: Our experimental results confirm the superiority of our method in terms of improved data discrimination and aesthetics of the treemaps.

task list.task: rate the aesthetics of the treemap
compare the size of the two highlighted blocks (adjacent) and click on the larger one

results: coloring method had a significant effect on aesthetic values (c-vpa better than random and sequential)

unproven results: there were no interaction for aesthetic values or size estimation accuracy
result based claims: we can conclude that our method can simultaneously improve aesthetics and data discrimination
